S2.T1.caption: Table 1. Abbreviations and their description.
S2.T1.table:
Abbreviation Description
CNN convolutional neural network (Kim, 2014)
Att attention network
AddAtt additive attention (Bahdanau et al., 2014)
MHSA multi-head self-attention (Vaswani et al., 2017)
PLM pre-trained language model
PLM[CLS] the PLM’s output [CLS] token representation
PLMtokenemb+Att PLM’s token embeddings pooled with an attention network (Wu et al., 2021b)
SE sentence encoder
\hdashlineCon concatenation
Linear linear layer
\hdashlineLF late fusion (Iana et al., 2023b)
GRU gated recurrent unit (Cho et al., 2014)
CandAware candidate-aware user encoder (Qi et al., 2022)
references: Content-based neural news recommenders consists of a dedicated (i) news encoder (NE) and a (ii) user encoder (UE) (Wu et al., 2023). The NE transforms different input features (e.g., title, abstract, categories, named entities, images) of a news article (Wu et al., 2023). The NE transforms different input features (e.g., title, abstract, categories, named entities, images) of a news article n 𝑛 n italic_n into a latent news representation n 𝑛 n italic_n n n 𝑛 𝑛 𝑛n nitalic_n italic_n into a latent news representation 𝐧 𝐧 \mathbf{n} bold_n . The dot product of the two embeddings 𝐧 c superscript 𝐧 𝑐 \mathbf{n}^{c} bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐧 c superscript 𝐧 𝑐 \mathbf{n}^{c} bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 𝐧 c 𝐧 𝐧c c superscript 𝐧 𝑐 superscript 𝐧 𝑐 superscript superscript𝐧 𝐧𝑐 𝑐\mathbf{n}^{c} \mathbf{n}^{c}bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐮 𝐮 \mathbf{u} bold_u is the most common scoring function 𝐮 𝐮 \mathbf{u} bold_u 𝐮 𝐮 𝐮 𝐮 𝐮\mathbf{u} \mathbf{u}bold_u bold_u is the most common scoring function (Wu et al., 2019b). NNRs are trained via conventional classification objectives (Wu et al., 2019b). NNRs are trained via conventional classification objectives (Huang et al., 2013) with negative sampling (Huang et al., 2013) with negative sampling (Wu et al., 2022a), or contrastive objectives (Wu et al., 2022a), or contrastive objectives (Iana et al., 2023c; Liu et al., 2023). The building blocks of NNRs (i.e., NE, UE, scoring function, training objective) altogether drive the overall performance of the recommender. Since the NE and UE determine what information of the documents and users is embedded by the model, and ultimately, propagated through the recommendation pipeline, both types of encoders play a similarly important role in model selection. We introduce the abbreviations used for the remainder of the paper in Table (Iana et al., 2023c; Liu et al., 2023). The building blocks of NNRs (i.e., NE, UE, scoring function, training objective) altogether drive the overall performance of the recommender. Since the NE and UE determine what information of the documents and users is embedded by the model, and ultimately, propagated through the recommendation pipeline, both types of encoders play a similarly important role in model selection. We introduce the abbreviations used for the remainder of the paper in Table 1.

S3.T2.caption: Table 2. Text encoder architectures.
S3.T2.table:
Text Embedding Type Text Encoder References
word embeddings CNN + AddAtt (Wu et al., 2019b; An et al., 2019; Wu et al., 2019a, c; Sheu and Li, 2020; Santosh et al., 2020)
MHSA + AddAtt (Gao et al., 2018; Wu et al., 2019d, 2020d, 2020e; Ge et al., 2020; Tran et al., 2021; Qi et al., 2021; Wu et al., 2022b, 2021a, 2021d; Qi et al., 2022; Wang et al., 2022)
CNN + MHSA + AddAtt (Qi et al., 2020)
\hdashlinelanguage model PLMtokenemb+Att (Wu et al., 2020c, 2021b; Zhang et al., 2021a, b)
PLM[CLS] (Jia et al., 2021; Wu et al., 2022c; Li et al., 2022; Shivaram et al., 2022; Iana et al., 2023c)
SE (Iana et al., 2024)
references:
We list the most used types of text encoders that we consider in our analysis in Table 2, alongside examples of NNRs using them. We distinguish between text encoders that rely on pretrained word embeddings, contextualized by means of convolutional or self-attention networks, and the more recent architectures that employ pretrained language models.<sup class="ltx_note_mark">1</sup>
1<sup class="ltx_note_mark">1</sup>
11Note that in this work we do not evaluate encoders which rely on news or user graphs, as such graphs are heavily dataset-dependent. We instead focus on the most used core components of encoders, and leave the analysis of graph-based techniques for future work.
We additionally consider the most common multi-feature aggregation approaches used to integrate text and other content feature (e.g., category) embeddings into the unified news representation, as shown in Table 3.

S3.T3.caption: Table 3. Multi-feature aggregation strategies for combining textual and categorical representations of news.
S3.T3.table:
Multi-feature aggregation References
AddAtt (Wu et al., 2019b; Santosh et al., 2020; Wu et al., 2021a; Sun et al., 2021; Raza and Ding, 2021; Wang et al., 2022)
Linear (Tran et al., 2021; Qi et al., 2022)
Con (An et al., 2019; Ge et al., 2020; Han et al., 2021)

references: User Encoder Architectures. Parameterized UEs represent the most popular user modeling technique. They learn user representations by means of sequential or attentive networks that contextualize the embeddings of clicked news based on patterns in the user’s click behavior. UEs can be further differentiated into candidate-agnostic (i.e., users are encoded separately from candidate news) and candidate-aware (i.e., the user-level aggregation contextualizes the embeddings of clicked news against the embedding of each candidate) encoders (Iana et al., 2023b). More recently, (Iana et al., 2023b). More recently, Iana et al. (2023b) proposed the parameter-free late fusion ( Iana et al. (2023b) proposed the parameter-free late fusion (LF) approach. LF first averages the clicked news embeddings 𝐧 i u superscript subscript 𝐧 𝑖 𝑢 \mathbf{n}_{i}^{u} bold_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to a user embedding 𝐧 i u superscript subscript 𝐧 𝑖 𝑢 \mathbf{n}_{i}^{u} bold_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 𝐧 i u 𝐧 𝐧i iu u superscript subscript 𝐧 𝑖 𝑢 superscript subscript 𝐧 𝑖 𝑢 superscript superscript subscript 𝐧 𝑖 subscript subscript𝐧 𝐧𝑖 𝑖𝑢 𝑢\mathbf{n}_{i}^{u} \mathbf{n}_{i}^{u}bold_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to a user embedding 1 N ⁢ ∑ i = 1 N 𝐧 i u = 𝐮 1 𝑁 subscript superscript 𝑁 𝑖 1 superscript subscript 𝐧 𝑖 𝑢 𝐮 \frac{1}{N}{\sum^{N}_{i=1}\mathbf{n}_{i}^{u}}=\mathbf{u} divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_u .
